Name: Is there a distinct category of dual for verbal agreement with a dual subject?
Is non-agreement in number between the nominal subject and verbal predicate possible?
Can finite verbs agree in number with the nominal object?
Can an adnominal property word agree with the noun in case?
Comment: There is no case agreement within noun phrases at all.

Name: Are there cases that do not show agreement in terms of case?
Comment: There is no case agreement within noun phrases at all.

Name: Can adpositions be used to mark core verbal arguments?
Can adpositions be used to mark non-core/oblique verbal arguments?
Comment: It could however be reasoned that postpositions that encode oblique arguments have been subject to morphologization and that it is only description tradition and orthographic norms that prevent them from being considered case suffixes (see EG 163-164).

Name: Can non-finite clauses entail a special way for a core argument (S/A) marking?
Comment: “Possessive suffixes can be added to the long form of the gerund of prior action” (RHM 170). The same applies to the gerund of future action (RHM 172), participles (RHM 154-162); the picture is more complicated with postpositions (RHM 232) where the government depends on the individual postposition.

Name: Can non-finite clauses entail a special way for a core argument (P) marking?
Do characteristics of object referent (topicality, animacy, definiteness) influence object marking?
Comment: Differential object marking is only possible in non-finite clauses.

Name: Does object marking correlate with aspectuality?
Comment:
There is differential object marking only in non-finite clauses. e.g. кол кыч-аш
[kol kət͡ʃ-ɑʃ] (fish.NOM catch-INF) ‘to fish, to catch fish’, кол-ым кыч-аш [kol-əm kət͡ʃ-ɑʃ] (fish-ACC catch-INF)
‘to catch a fish’. The motivation for using nominative objects presumably lies on the intersection of definiteness and aspectuality.

Name: Does the marking of the object depend on the verb conjugation form?
Is there differential subject marking?
Can S and A be conflated morphologically across clause boundaries, i.e. act as syntactic pivot?
Can S and P be conflated morphologically across clause boundaries, i.e. act as syntactic pivot?
Is there a grammatical device for habituality?
Comment: Compound past tenses I & II (formed by present-tense form followed by ‘to be’ in the third person singular, either in simple past I or II) are habitual (the distinction between them is evidential). Also, aspectual auxiliaries (light verbs) илаш ‘to live’ and шогалаш ‘to stand up’ can be coupled with a converb and give the resulting pairing a habitual value.

Name: Is there a grammatical device for frequentative?
Comment:
Numerous defivational suffixes: -л [-l]: лӹмдӓш [lə̈mdɑʃ] ‘to name’ → лӹмдӹлӓш [lə̈mdə̈læʃ] ‘to call names’, -ешт [-eʃt]: колаш [kolɑʃ] ‘to hear’ → колышташ [koləʃtɑʃ] ‘to listen’, -кал [-kɑl]: айыраш [ɑjərɑʃ] ‘to separate’ → айыркалаш [ɑjərkɑlɑʃ] ‘to sort’,
-ед [-ed]: пуаш [puɑʃ] ‘to give’ → пуэдӓш [puedæʃ] ‘to hand out’. Also auxiliary опташ ‘to place (several items)’.

Name: Is there a grammatical device for progressivity?
Comment: Aspectual auxiliary (light verb) ӹлӓш [ə̈læʃ] ‘to live’ is used.

Name: Is it common to use a verb in the present tense for future time reference?
Comment: Especially in combination with atelic verbs or verbal pairings, the verb тӹнгӓлӓш [tə̈ŋgælæʃ] ‘to begin’ is used as a future auxiliary.

Name: Is there a grammatical device for immediate future?
Comment: Simple past tense 1 forms can, in a structure presumably borrowed from Russian, be used to denote something that is about to happen in the immediate future.

Name: Is there a grammatical device for pluperfect?
Comment: The usual way of expressing this is using the converb of prior action. Also simple past III & IV (distinction between them is evidential), formed by a simple past II form followed by a past-tense form (simple past I and II respectively) of the verb ‘to be’ in the third person singular, are “used to denote an action that preceded another action or is interrupted by it”.

Name: Can aspect be expressed overtly on the negative marker?
Can tense be expressed overtly on the negative marker?
Is there grammatical marking of mirativity?
Comment:
The particle ылын [ələn] (‘to be’ in simple past II, 3SG) is placed after verbs in sentences “in reference to inferences, knowledge that was previously unknown, etc.” - including surprising events.
However, there is no grammatical disctinction between evidential and mirative forms: тӹдӹ шыжар-жы доно ӓрня нӓрӹ хынален кашт-еш ыл-ын [tə̈də̈ ʃəʒɑr-ʒə dono ærɲæ nærə̈ xənɑlen kɑʃt-eʃ əl-ən] (3SG little_sister-PX3SG with week about for_a_visit go-PRS.3SG) 'It turned out that s/he stayed at her/his sister’s for about a week'.

Name: Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of desire or wish?
Is there morphological marking for irrealis (e.g. hypothetical state of affairs)?
Comment: A conditional suffix -гецӹ [-get͡sə̈] can be found, but is marginal in usage: in modern language it is only used on the verb ‘to be’, ылгецӹ [əlget͡sə̈]; this form is used as a particle in combination with indicative forms.

Name: Are verbs marked in a specific mood in counterfactual conditional clauses?
Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of deontic necessity?
Comment: There is a necessitive infinitive with the ending -мыла/-мӹлӓ [-məlɑ/-mə̈læ] and a future-necessitive participle in -шашлык/-шашлӹк [-ʃɑʃlək/-ʃæʃlək].

Name: Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of epistemic possibility?
Comment: The future-necessitive participle in --шашлык/-шӓшлык [-ʃɑʃlək/-ʃæʃlək], which prototypically denotes necessity, can in some cases be used in this function. See also UT028.

Name: Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of deontic possibility?
Is there morphological marking on the verb used to express indirect commands/wishes etc. directed to the 3Sg?
Is there morphological marking on the verb used to express indirect commands/wishes etc. directed to the 1Sg?
Is it common to use the imperative/jussive in complement clauses introduced by predicates expressing wish/desire/will?
Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of apprehension?
Is there reflexive conjugation?
Comment: Realized by a highly productive derivational suffix.

Name: Are there syntactically ditransitive verbs?
Comment: One of the prototypical usage situations for the dative, which unlike the dative in Turkic or Ob-Ugric languages is not used in a spatial sense

Name: Can non-singular 2nd and 3rd person have the same person/number marking or morphosyntactic treatment?
Can an impersonal (or passive) form be used instead of a finite plural form with an overt subject expression?
Can third person plural verb forms be used for impersonal reference?
Comment: Probably Russian influence.

Name: Can second person singular verb forms be used in generic meaning?
Are clauses with only infinitive predicates possible?
Can verbs in purposive subordinate clauses be in bare infinitive form?
Are there sentences without overt verbal arguments (e.g. weather verbs)?
Comment: This typically happens in Mari (only) with causative verb forms. The verbs meaning ‘rain’, ‘snow’ , and ‘blow’ (wind) require a subject.

Name: Is copula needed for predicate nominals in the 3rd person form of the present tense?
Comment: Copula is not needed 3rd person form of the present tense, e.g. тӹдӹ тымдышы [tə̈də̈ təmdəʃə] (3SG teacher) ‘s/he is a teacher’.

Name: Is a copula needed for predicate nominals in the past and/or future tense?
Can locative adverbial phrases act as predicates without a copula?
Can the same coordinating conjunction be used for NPs, VPs, and clauses?
Does existential negation have a separate operator?
Can standard negation be asymmetric in the present tense?
Can non-finite dependent clauses use the standard negation construction?
Is there a special negator that combines with non-finite forms?
Comment: The element -ды-/-дӹ -[-də- ~ -tə- ~ -də̈- ~ -tə̈-] contained in numerous non-finite forms.

Name: Are there special negative non-finite forms?
Is there an impersonal passive construction?
Comment: Realized by a highly productive derivational suffix.

Name: Are there nonfinite forms specialized on the relativization of particular core participants, e.g. subjects (S/A), direct objects (P), absolutive participants (S/P)?
Are there nonfinite forms that can relativize at least all core participants (S/A/P) and possibly also some noncore participants, e.g. locative adverbials, instruments, etc.?
Are there nonfinite forms that can relativize at least some noncore participants, e.g. locative adverbials or instruments, but cannot relativize all or some of the core participants, e.g. subjects?
Is there a specialized negative participial form, which cannot be analyzed as a specific participial marker + negation marker?
Comment: While the participle in -дымы is historically complex (negation element + ending of passive participle), it is treated as a unit in modern language.

Name: Is there a future participle?
Are there participles that can encode their subject by possessive suffixes?
Can subject in at least some participial subordinate clauses be encoded in the same way as in independent clauses?
Are there participles that obligatorily agree with the nouns they modify in case and number (in all contexts)?
Comment: No agreement between modifiers and superordinate nouns in general; participles do not differ from this norm.

Name: Are there nonfinite forms that can be used both as participles and action nominalizations?
Comment: Possible with all participles but the active participle.

Name: Are there nonfinite forms that can be used both as participles and agentive nominalizations?
Are there nonfinite forms that can be used both as participles and converbs without any additional morphological material, such as case markers?
Is OV the neutral order in affirmative imperative clauses?
Comment: The basic word order is SOV. There is no obvious deviation from the norm in the imperative, at least not on a regular basis

Name: Is it possible to place an object between the negative marker and the main verb in imperative constructions?
Comment: The negation verb and the connegative form are tied to one another tightly. It is unusual for other elements (e.g., adverbs, pronouns) to occupy the space between them and it is unusual for the word order to change – the connegative form by default follows the negation verb.

Name: Are there preverbs?
Are there verbal prefixes?
Is there diminutive (hypocoristic) marking on verbs?
Can modifiers of action nominalization in agent and patient roles both be encoded like possessors?
Can the modifier of action nominalization in patient role (e.g. "drinking of coffee") be encoded like the direct object?
Do core adjectives agree with the subject noun in number in the predicative position?
Comment: There is no agreement, e.g. нӹнӹ пуры ыл-ыт [nə̈nə̈ purə əl-ət] (3PL kind be-PRS.3PL) ‘they are kind’.

Name: Is it possible to form synthetic superlative?
Comment: Analytic formation is used: сек яжо (SPRL good) ‘the best’;сек < Russian всех.

Name: Can adpositions have person/number marking?
Are there separate adpositions to express goal, source, and location (without there being syncretism)?
Is case compounding possible?
Are there case categories only found in pronouns?
Does the numeral modification of a noun have an effect on its case selection?
Comment: The nominative case is used, e.g. карандаш [kɑrɑndɑʃ] ‘pencil’, кок карандаш [kok kɑrɑndɑʃ] ‘two pencils’.

Name: Is the singular form of the noun also used with numerals bigger than 1?
Is there a genitive case that has an affix?
Is there a case used to express indirect object/receiver/goal (different from a local case)?
Comment: One of the prototypical usage situations for the dative, which unlike the dative in Turkic or Ob-Ugric languages is not used in a spatial sense.

Name: Is there a terminative case?
Is there a separate case to indicate without what/who an action takes place / does not take place?
Is there a separate case to mark the motion along or by the referent of the noun (prolative)?
Is there a locative case that marks goal?
Is there a locative case that marks location?
Is there a locative case that marks source?
Is there case syncretism of goal and location marking?
Is there case syncretism of location and source marking?
Are there two sets of local cases?
Is there a third set of local cases?
Is there a separate case for marking the means by which something is carried out (instrumental) and/or accompaniement (comitative)?
Comment: NB! The so-called comitative case mentioned in Mari grammars and textbooks has a radically different function.

Name: Is there a separate case for marking accompaniment, which is different from the instrumental?
Is there a separate case for marking the result of change (translative) and/or a state of being (essive)?
Is there a separate case for marking the state of being (essive), which is different from the translative?
Is there a separate morphological marker for expressing equative meaning?
Comment: “The comparative case is used in answer to the questions кӱлӓ [kylæ]? ‘like whom, as whom’ and мала? ‘like what, as what’”

Name: Is there an inflectional nominal marker for expressing benefactive or destinative semantics independent from the dative?
Comment: The dative is used to mark benefactors.

Name: Is there in addition to the basic declension a declension different from a possessive declension?
Is it possible to use singular with paired body parts/clothing/accessories that accompany them?
Can the marking of the possessor in the attributive construction vary?
Can the possessor in the attributive construction be encoded with the nominative?
Comment: It should be noted that inanimate nouns traditionally did not occur in the genitive at all; inanimate nouns serving as a modification do occur in the nominative, e.g. Вена университет [Venɑ universitet] (Vienna.NOM university) ‘University of Vienna’ (see mrj.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%92%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B0)

Name: Is non-singular possession marked in the possessive declension?
Can 2Sg possessive suffix be used to mark definiteness?
Can 3Sg possessive suffix be used to mark definiteness?
Comment: The possessive suffix is used to indicate a reference to something previously discussed or otherwise salient to the conversation. It is especially commonly used to refer to a subset of a larger whole that is salient.

Name: Is there human vs. non-human distinction distinction in independent interrogative pronouns?
When used as a relative pronoun, is it common to use 'who' for animates other than humans?
When used as a relative pronoun, is it common to use 'who' for inanimates?
Can a demonstrative stem be used in the function of a pronoun with 3rd person singular human referent?
Comment: “Both in Hill Mari and in Meadow Mari, the pronouns тидӹ [tidə̈] (тиде [tide]) ‘this’ and тӹдӹ [tə̈də̈] (тудо [tudo]) ‘that’ have short forms ти [ti] ~ тӹ [tə̈] (ты [tə] ~ ту [tu]). The long forms are used when they stand on their own and are subject to nominal inflection. Before a noun as an attribute, in Hill Mari only the short form is used, whereas in Meadow Mari either the short or long form can be used.”

Name: Are there possessive suffixes whose position in relation to case/number suffixes can vary?
Comment: The “degrees of freedom” depend on the case.

Name: Is the order of number and case suffixes fixed across the paradigm the same?
Are there different words for mother’s brother and father’s brother?
Are there different words for younger and older relative for other relations than siblings?
Is there animacy distinction for both concepts 'new/young' and 'old'?
Is there distinction for both 'warm' and 'cold' based on whether referring to weather or to temperature of objects?
Source: Savatkova 347; RHM 195; Jeremy Bradley and Nadezhda Krasnova (p.c. 2020)
Comment: The same word is used in both occasions, e.g. шокшы игечӹ [ʃokʃo iget͡ʃə̈] ‘hot weather’ - шокшы вӹд [ʃokʃo və̈d] ‘hot water’; ӱштӹ игечӹ [yʃtə̈ iget͡ʃə̈] ‘cold weather’ - ӱштӹ вӹд [yʃtə̈ və̈d] ‘cold water’.

Name: Is there contrastive length of consonants?
Comment:
Geminate (long) consonants only occur at morpheme boundaries.

нӹллӹ [nə̈lːə̈] ‘forty’ (← нӹл [nə̈l] ‘four’ + лу [lu] ‘ten’)

Name: Is there contrastive length of vowels?
Comment: Reduced vowels are shorter than full vowels, but there is a clear qualitative difference between non-reduced and reduced vowels, so it cannot be reasoned that vowel length alone is distinctive.

Name: Is there contrast between short and long unstressed vowels?
Comment: No distinctive vowel length at all.

Name: Is there contrast in duration of geminate consonants?
Are there more than two phonological quantities?
Are there extralong syllables?
Comment: No distinctive vowel length at all; geminate consonants only at morpheme boundaries.

Name: Is the main foot structure trochaic?
Is there lexically distinctive word stress?
Is there morphologically conditioned stress?
Comment: In Hill Mari, some suffixes are stressed (usually the penultimate syllable is stressed in Hill Mari), e.g. the comparative suffix.

Name: Is there fixed primary stress?
Comment: The penultimate syllable is generally stressed: ӓтямлӓн [æˈcæmlæn] ‘to my father’. However: ( 1 ) a number of suffixes are stressed in violation of these rules, ( 2 ) if the penultimate syllable has a reduced vowel and there is a full vowel preceding that syllable, the stress shifts to the previous syllable.

Name: Is there stress in heavy syllables?
Comment: Syllable structure has no transparent effect on where stress falls.

Name: Is there non-initial primary stress?
Comment: The penultimate syllable is generally stressed. However: ( 1 ) a number of suffixes are stressed in violation of these rules, ( 2 ) if the penultimate syllable has a reduced vowel and there is a full vowel preceding that syllable, the stress shifts to the previous syllable.

Name: Is there palatal vowel harmony?
Comment: Consistent palato-velar vowel harmony.

Name: Is there velar vowel harmony?
Comment: In Hill Mari, consistent palato-velar vowel harmony.

Name: Is there labial vowel harmony?
Are there rising diphthongs?
Are there lowering diphthongs?
Is there qualitative contrast between subsets of short and long vowels?
Are there full vs. reduced vowels as contrastive subsets?
Is there front high rounded vowel ü [y]?
Is there front midhigh rounded vowel ö [ø]?
Is there back high unrounded vowel ï [ɯ]?
Is there back midhigh unrounded vowel ë [ɤ]?
Comment: There are however two reduced vowels with similar values: ы [ə], ӹ [ə̈].

Name: Is there back low round vowel [ɒ]?
Is there contrast between low and mid front vowels (ä [æ] vs. e [e])?
Are there word-initial consonant clusters?
Comment: Very rare and the effect of a fairly recent loss of reduced vowels that did not happen in all varieties of Mari.

Name: Are there word-internal consonant clusters in syllable onset?
Are there consonant clusters in syllable coda?
Are there clusters of three or more consonants in a word between vowels?
Are there word-final clusters of three or more consonants?
Are there palatalized dentals?
Comment: The palatal consonants [ʎ], [ɲ], [c] are frequently mislabelled as palatalized. Palatalized pronunciation under Russian influence and especially in Russian loan words does happen.

Name: Are there palatalized labials and velars?
Comment: Only in Russian loan words among contemporary speakers.

Name: Is there palatal stop [c]?
Is there palatal nasal [ɲ]?
Is there palatal lateral [ʎ]?
Is there phonemic velar nasal [ŋ]?
Comment: However, phonemic status is debated.

Name: Is there dental affricate [t͡s]?
Is there non-alveolar affricate (e.g. [t͡ʃ], [͡cɕ])?
Is there a phonological contrast between [s] and postalveolar sibilant [ʃ]?
Are there voiced plosives [b, g, d]?
Comment: Historically as allophones of the fricatives /β/, /ɣ/, /ð/ after homorganic nasals, i.e.: [mb], [ŋg], [nd]. Today /ɣ/ and /ð/ are widely pronounced as [g] and [d].

Name: Is there glottal stop [ˀ]?
Is there phonological contrast between plain and labial velar consonants (e.g. [k] vs. [kʷ])?
Is there a constraint on word-initial r?
Comment: It is uncommon, but not excluded. There are some words of proto-Uralic origin that have an initial r. There are some varieties in which intial r is preceded by prothetic ə, however, presumably under Chuvash indluence.

Name: Is there laryngeal fricative [h]?
Is there voiced velar fricative [ɣ]?
Comment: Today historic /ɣ/ is commonly pronounced as [g].

Name: Is there voiceless velar fricative [x]?
Comment: Cf. Meadow Mari калык [kɑlək].

Name: Is there voiced dental fricative [ð]?
Comment: Today historic [ð] is commonly pronounced as [d].

Name: Is there phonemic labio-velar approximant [w]?
Comment: Among younger speakers it is commony pronounced as [v].

Name: Is there voiceless labiodental fricative [f]?
Comment: In Hill Mari, “/f/ is often said to have phonemic value in Hill Mari, but its usage is quite restricted here as well”.

Name: Is there radical qualitative consonant gradation?
Is there quantitative consonant gradation?
